Literature Review: The naked mole-rat (Heterocephalus glaber) has emerged as a fascinating model organism for studying healthy aging and longevity. These small, hairless rodents native to East Africa have captivated researchers due to their extraordinary lifespan of over 37 years, which is exceptionally long for a rodent of their size. This review aims to synthesize current knowledge on the unique characteristics of naked mole-rats (NMRs) that contribute to their delayed aging phenotype and resistance to age-related diseases.One of the most striking features of NMRs is their negligible senescence, a phenomenon characterized by the lack of an age-related increase in mortality rate. Buffenstein et al. (2008) reported that NMRs maintain high levels of activity, reproduction, and physiological function well into their third decade of life, with no observable decline in most biomarkers of aging. This is in stark contrast to other rodents, which typically show rapid aging and increased mortality after just a few years.The exceptional longevity of NMRs is accompanied by a remarkable resistance to cancer. Delaney et al. (2013) conducted a comprehensive study of NMR tissues and found no evidence of spontaneous neoplasia, even in animals over 30 years old. This cancer resistance has been attributed to various mechanisms, including enhanced cellular senescence and tumor suppressor activity. Tian et al. (2013) identified a unique form of high-molecular-mass hyaluronan in NMR cells that contributes to their cancer resistance by triggering early contact inhibition.Another intriguing aspect of NMR biology is their ability to thrive in hypoxic environments. As subterranean mammals living in large colonies, NMRs are regularly exposed to low oxygen conditions. Park et al. (2017) demonstrated that NMRs have evolved specialized hemoglobin with a higher affinity for oxygen, allowing them to extract oxygen more efficiently from their environment. This adaptation not only enables their survival in underground burrows but may also contribute to their longevity by reducing oxidative stress.The social structure of NMRs is another factor that may influence their longevity. Jarvis et al. (1994) described the complex eusocial organization of NMR colonies, which is unique among mammals. This social structure, reminiscent of that seen in some insects, may provide evolutionary advantages that contribute to their extended lifespan. The division of labor within colonies, with only a few individuals responsible for reproduction, could allow for the allocation of resources towards somatic maintenance in non-breeding individuals.At the molecular level, NMRs exhibit several adaptations that may contribute to their longevity. Pérez et al. (2009) found that NMRs maintain high levels of protein quality control throughout their lifespan, with more stable proteins and increased proteasome activity compared to mice. This enhanced proteostasis may prevent the accumulation of damaged proteins that typically occurs with age.Furthermore, NMRs show remarkable resistance to oxidative stress, a major contributor to aging in most organisms. Andziak et al. (2006) reported that despite having similar levels of oxidative damage to short-lived rodents, NMRs exhibit superior repair and clearance mechanisms that prevent the accumulation of oxidative damage over time.The brain aging process in NMRs is also of particular interest, as these animals show resistance to neurodegenerative diseases. Edrey et al. (2013) found that NMRs maintain neurogenesis and cognitive function well into old age, with no evidence of age-related neuronal loss or accumulation of amyloid-beta, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease in humans.Recent genomic and transcriptomic studies have provided further insights into the molecular basis of NMR longevity. Kim et al. (2011) sequenced the NMR genome and identified several unique genetic features, including changes in genes related to thermogenesis, DNA repair, and telomere maintenance. These genetic adaptations may contribute to the NMR's exceptional lifespan and cancer resistance.While significant progress has been made in understanding the biology of NMRs, many questions remain unanswered. Future research should focus on elucidating the precise mechanisms underlying their cancer resistance, hypoxia tolerance, and delayed aging. Additionally, comparative studies with other long-lived and short-lived species could provide valuable insights into conserved longevity pathways.In conclusion, the naked mole-rat serves as an invaluable model for studying healthy aging and age-related disease resistance. Their unique adaptations to a challenging subterranean environment have resulted in extraordinary longevity and resilience. By unraveling the secrets of NMR biology, researchers hope to gain insights that could potentially be translated into interventions to promote healthy aging in humans.
